qas.question: What would you call a beer that has not been filtered or pasteurized?
What would you call a frame that holds the cask of beer horizontally when it arrives at the pub?
What temperature are cask ales stored at before being tapped?
How long does it take for sediment to settle and clear after a cask ale has been tapped?

answers.text: from several hours to several days

qas.question: What tool is used to pull beer from a cask to serve?
What are cask ales termed by the CARMA organisation?
What cools at a temperature of 11-13 degrees F?
What cools at a temperature of 52-55 degrees C?
What takes beer several hours to do after being tapped and vented?

context: <a0_0>Cask-conditioned ales<a0_0/> (or cask ales) are unfiltered and unpasteurised beers. These beers are termed "<b5_0>real ale<b5_0/>" by the CAMRA organisation. Typically, when <b6_0>a <b7_0>cask<b7_0/><b6_0/> arrives in a pub, it is placed horizontally on a frame called a "<a1_0>stillage<a1_0/>" which is designed to hold it steady and at the right angle, and then allowed to cool to cellar temperature (typically between 11–13 °C or <a2_0>52–55 °F<a2_0/>), before being tapped and vented—a tap is driven through a (usually rubber) bung at the bottom of one end, and a hard spile or other implement is used to open a hole in the side of the cask, which is now uppermost. The act of stillaging and then venting a beer in this manner typically disturbs all the sediment, so it must be left for a suitable period to <b8_0>"drop"<b8_0/> (clear) again, as well as to fully condition—this period can take anywhere <a3_0>from several hours to several days<a3_0/>. At this point the beer is ready to sell, either being pulled through a beer line with <a4_0>a hand pump<a4_0/>, or simply being "gravity-fed" directly into the glass.
